channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Meat Supplier of McDonald’s and KFC Gets the Ax
item.description: A television program has captured footage of workers at a meat processing facility using out-of-date chicken and beef to make burger patties and chicken products for McDonald’s and KFC.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL GOUGH
item.media:description: Customers dining at a KFC restaurant in Shanghai.

item.title: Havens Are Few, if Not Far, for Palestinians in Gaza Strip
item.description: A vast majority of Gazans are effectively trapped, unable to seek refugee status across an international border.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Thousands of residents fled the Shejaiya neighborhood in the east of Gaza City on Sunday morning.

item.title: South Sudanese Rebels Clash With Government Soldiers in Town Near Ethiopian Border
item.description: The attack on Nasir, in the oil-rich Upper Nile State, is the biggest threat so far to the shaky cease-fire signed on May 9.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Rotterdam Journal: Dutch Grief Abounds, but Mourning Stays Local
item.description: There has been no day of public mourning declared in the Netherlands for the nearly 200 citizens killed aboard Flight 17; nobody is wearing black; flags flying at half-mast are rarely seen.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: Churchgoers prayed Sunday during a special mass in Saint Vitus Church in Hilversum, Netherlands.

item.title: Trying to Slow the Illegal Flow of Young Migrants
item.description: Bus operators in Honduras say they are noticing a decline in the number of unaccompanied children headed to the border, and the Border Patrol has reported a dip in the number of people apprehended in Texas.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: Africans Open Fuller Wallets to the Future
item.description: Across sub-Saharan Africa, consumer demand is fueling the continent’s economies in new ways, driving hopes that Africa will emerge as a success story.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:description: A saleswoman in a red shirt talking to shoppers at a furniture and appliance store in the Daveytown mall outside Johannesburg.

item.title: Neighborhood Ravaged on Deadliest Day So Far for Both Sides in Gaza
item.description: The withering assault on the neighborhood of Shejaiya, and the death of 87 Palestinians and 13 Israeli soldiers and officers, appeared to shake the international community.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: A doctor wept on Sunday amid the bodies of four dead children in an overflowing morgue of Shifa Hospital in Gaza City.

item.title: Bodies From Malaysia Airlines Flight Are Stuck in Ukraine, Held Hostage Over Distrust
item.description: World leaders expressed a growing outrage over pro-Russian rebels’ refusal to cede authority over the site where the downed jet’s debris is scattered.
item.dc:creator: By SABRINA TAVERNISE and NOAH SNEIDER
item.media:description: A woman near the train cars, stuck in a war zone, protected herself from the smell on Sunday.

item.title: Kerry Says Russia Trained Separatists to Use Antiaircraft Missiles
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry stopped short of saying Russia provided the missile unit that downed Malaysia Airlines Flight 17.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Teacher and Restaurateurs Were Flight 17 Victims
item.description: Laurens van der Graaff, “impossible to dislike,” became a teacher like his parents, and Jenny Loh and Shun Po Fan, whose “dream was to please their guests,” ran restaurants.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Concern and Support for Iraqi Christians Forced by Militants to Flee Mosul
item.description: To meet a deadline by the ISIS militants, most Christians in Mosul, a community almost as old as Christianity itself, left with little more than the clothes they were wearing.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Iraqi Christians and Muslims attended a Christian church service in Baghdad on Sunday to show support for Christians forced to leave Mosul.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Russia's Anti-West Isolationism
item.description: The rhetoric emanating from the Kremlin has been one of the main drivers of support for the Ukrainian conflict.
item.dc:creator: By MAXIM TRUDOLYUBOV

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Give Us a Bishop in High Heels
item.description: Cheers from St. Mildred and her sisters, for the Church of England.
item.dc:creator: By JANE GARDAM

item.title: In Gaza, Epithets Are Fired and Euphemisms Give Shelter
item.description: In a clash of narratives, officials from both Israel and Gaza advise supporters on the language and images that should be used on social media platforms.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Racy Photos Were Often Shared at N.S.A., Snowden Says
item.description: Edward J. Snowden said lax oversight allowed for members of the United States military to pass around sexually explicit photos they had intercepted.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: U.S. Naval Ties With China Advance, Symbolically
item.description: While the United States chief of naval operations was spending time aboard China’s aircraft carrier, the Chinese Navy was participating for the first time in the United States-led multinational exercises off Hawaii.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: A Chinese military honor guard prepared to welcome the United States chief of naval operations, Adm. Jonathan W. Greenert, outside Beijing on July 15.

item.title: Kerry Expresses Frustration Over Civilian Toll in Gaza
item.description: While publicly Secretary of State John Kerry strongly defended Israel’s right to act against Hamas, an open microphone caught Mr. Kerry’s cellphone remarks to an aide.
item.dc:creator: By BRIAN KNOWLTON and MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: International Education: Adult Education Eases Path to Career Change
item.description: Part-time classes prove useful when thinking about making a career change.
item.dc:creator: By GINANNE BROWNELL
item.media:description: A student in art class at London’s City Lit, which offers dozens of short-term courses.

item.title: Kerry Says Russia Trained Separatists to Use Antiaircraft Missiles
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry said on Sunday, “We know for certain that the separatists have a proficiency that they’ve gained by training from Russians as to how to use these sophisticated SA-11 systems.”
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and BRIAN KNOWLTON

item.title: As Anger Rises Over Crash, Malaysian Government Is Reluctant to Assign Blame
item.description: Officials have so far avoided joining the United States and many other countries in openly attributing the disaster to the Russian government.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY and KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: In Hospitals Across Gaza, Scenes of Chaos and Grief
item.description: Hospitals that were poorly equipped and staffed even before the Israeli military operation are struggling to cope with a surge of casualties from a war that continues to intensify.
item.dc:creator: By FARES AKRAM and ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Despite Israeli Push in Gaza, Hamas Fighters Slip Through Tunnels
item.description: Even as Israeli forces moved to demolish militants’ tunnels into Israel, several Hamas fighters slipped through passages on Saturday and fought gun battles with Israeli soldiers.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Israeli troops fired toward the Gaza Strip from their position near the border on Saturday. Israeli strikes killed 20 people in Gaza, pushing the death toll above 300.

item.title: Attack Kills at Least 21 Egyptian Soldiers at Checkpoint in Western Desert
item.description: A military official said about 20 gunmen in weapon-mounted vehicles took a checkpoint by surprise in Egypt’s western desert, killing at least 20 soldiers.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Palestinians Find Show of Support Lacking From Arab Leaders Amid Offensive
item.description: The governments were accused of dithering at critical moments, and at one point, Egypt even blamed Hamas, rather than Israel, for dozens of Palestinian deaths.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Relatives transported the bodies of the Abu Jarad family to a cemetery in Gaza City on Saturday.

item.title: With Jet Strike, War in Ukraine Is Felt Globally
item.description: The downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 rippled across multiple continents, bringing home in vivid relief the consequences of a struggle that had seemed far removed for many.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:description: Emergency workers on Saturday carried a body from the site of the Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 crash in the Donetsk region. For many, the disaster brought home a struggle that had seemed distant.
